turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Discipline does.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: Well discipline and unconstitutionality are two different things and this court has said so.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that on the out, there are no judgment of a court-martial would be final until passed on by the Court of Claims.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: Absolutely not sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Close.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: No sir, not even close, miles apart, miles apart because I might point out that twice in 17 years the Court of Claims has exercised its jurisdiction and in the Augenblick case --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: For this case, well I am looking for the future.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: Well I might point out that there has been no flood in the Court of Claims and there won't be sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It be that they read Article 76 to say that no court has jurisdiction.
Couldn't it be that these people that didn't go to the Court of Claims read that literally, that the court didn't have jurisdictions, so why waste of time.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: Well now, I think the number there would at least eight times, at least seven times, Mr. Justice Marshall where these cases were taken to the Court of Claims, where the Court of Claims went through the exercise that the government now says was forbidden to of looking at the merits assume jurisdiction looked at the merits and denied the relief on grounds that there wasn't any constitutional exercise so that if there were any clubhouse for barracks and lawyers they have always existed and it hasn't been the language of the Article 76, that's inhibited this review, it's been the restraint of the Court of Claims.
The Court of Claims is looking, was it looking, but it was waiting until it was faced with a proper record and it didn't act until it was faced with a proper record.

Now if this man, if this man is denied review by the Court of Claims then among the various consequences the Jencks Act can be forgotten in the military because the military, the rule of law that will apply on the military is that anytime the prosecution has Jencks material he doesn't want to turn over to the defendant then he just doesn't turn it over and hopes the defendant can't prove that he didn't destroy it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's not the law, the case law of the Court of Military Appeals is it?
Isn't that the tribunal trusted basically with the development of the case law for court's martial in this area.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: That's correct sir, that's correct.
Now that is the case --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: MThey can be counted on to do so based on their past record.

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: No but as Mr. Weisl pointed out that there is an additional quantum of, well of rejection that's involved in the C.M.A's turning down a case simply much more than this court simply turning down a case and I would point out that in the Board of Review, the Board of Review's opinion which deals with this case that the law, the law now is as the law from the military since this went to the Court of Military Appeals and there was no review of this determination on Jencks, is that the burden, the clear burden and they couldn't be clear, it's in the record here.
The clear burden falls on the defendant to prove bad faith.
Now that has never been ruled on, that point have never before been ruled on by the C.M.A. so that that apparently is law of the military unless this court does something about it.
Now, this is Court is not sitting in a supervisory role over the C.M.A., I'm not pointing that out.

But I'm pointing out is one of the necessary consequences of this court's dealing with what is a clear constitutional question in terms of this man's right to defend himself would be the therapeutic effect on the military of this complete misconception of Jencks rights and it went not only to one point but it went to four points.

It went to the burden approved being put on the wrong party when a Jencks material is not produced, the failure to conduct in a camera examination of admitted notes, admitted Jencks materials, the failure to incorporate those notes into the record so that anybody the Court of Military Appeals or anybody else could review it and a failure to call a key witness to determine what happened to these States.
The witness that denied, it was taken on the witness in whose hands it disappeared.
Under circumstances that are most incriminating.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Sharlitt suppose the Court of Military Appeals that, taken this case instead of having refused to review it and had heard all of your arguments along this line and had to affirm the conviction of this man would you then, would the Court of Claims then be available to you?

turn.speaker: joseph_h_sharlitt
turn.label: Mr. Joseph H. Sharlitt
turn.text: Yes sir, it would.

Because the reason that the sole way to come -- again the sole way to determine the constitutionality of this action would be in this court and the only way that the commander could to this Court would then be through the Court of Claims under those circumstances the rule was, the scope of civilian review as enunciated in Burns versus Wilson is whether fair consideration has been given.

Now some consideration is not fair consideration, and when rules of law are completely misstated, I don't believe that any court would determine that this is fair consideration and I would say that on the facts of this case, the constitutional issue has been raised in these Jencks Act violations, that the legislative history indicates that the Court of Claims neither in 1948 or 1950 was exercised in this jurisdiction, nothing was said about them and point of fact the only thing was said what to the effect -- was to the effect in a report that was filed in the congressional record that the Court of Claims jurisdiction remained and under those circumstances this court cannot deprive servicemen of the right to come to this Court by silence and by implication.

section.heading: Argument of Francis J. Steiner, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Steiner?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, May it please the Court.
The court martial of the respondent Kenneth N. Juhl was fundamentally unfair.
The testimony against him was by a man named Hughes, was an accomplice.
Hughes's testimony was an admitted perjury, he had been engaged in black-marketing for years.
He was tried himself, sentenced and convicted.
Then he was approached and he was told that unless you testify implicate Juhl, we're going to retry you on other charges and you'll get five years imprisonment and a dishonorable discharge.
He had a foreign wife this would also -- prevented him from bringing his wife back to this country.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Was it put to him in just that language that you've said, where in the record --?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, Appendix III, pages 362 and 363 is an affidavit of an air policeman who had custody.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, he wasn't a witness.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, this is an affidavit in the board of correction proceedings Your Honor.
This affidavit of this technical sergeant who was an air policeman, who had custody of Juhl and he stated that these facts were told to him.
And this is controverted.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And this is the part of the record of the trial?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Not of the court-martial Your Honor, it was an affidavit submitted to the Correction Board, but it's part of this trial and part of this record Your Honor.

The other facts which are part of this trial show that after he agreed to implicate Juhl, he was given special privileges, he was given easy work, he was given permission at night to go to movies with this wife and to watch television with his wife and he was given Christmas leave, this is while he was serving a sentence he never left the base --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Let me revert just a moment, I've, I want to know if you're telling us precisely what you said and I'm looking at this affidavit and it says subsequent to airman Hughes' trial and prior to Sergeant Juhl's court-martial, this airman was advised that unless he agreed to appear as a prosecution witness and testify, he would be tried by a general court-martial and so forth.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You just told us that unless he testified and implicated this man now he didn't say that according to this affidavit.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor that he testified against Juhl that's what I meant--

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, it says that he --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: As a prosecution witness Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Testified for the prosecution.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: For the prosecution, as a prosecution witness.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But does that imply that he used to tell anything but the truth.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Not that alone Your Honor but when combined with all of these facts of this case, his testimony was replete within inconsistencies, with self contradiction.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No, I'm not quarreling with that, I just want, I just -- calling your attention to what you said and what the affidavit says.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor I think that -- well I interpreted that as a prosecution witness and it maybe a little more of an interpretation of it.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's all, that's all I don't want to interrupt your argument otherwise go ahead --.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor but combined with all of these facts and the inconsistencies and self contradictions under oath in his testimony, it was totally unreliable.

I think these facts alone were sufficient to raise a constitutional question of whether he had a fair trial and I do not believe he had a fair trial with untampered witnesses, when this type pressure was put upon a man of Hughes' character that would have a fair witness who would come in.
This man Hughes would have said anything -- if you look at his past record, if you look at his testimony under oath.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything to show that he did partner himself in this hearing?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor the closest to it -- one is he denied all these things but in this hearing, you could say this time he's telling the truth, but in the Article 32 proceedings, which is also part of these records, the discovery records, they're asking, would you lie under oath, would you lie under oath, and like he said yes that's part of the record to that -- now whether he's telling the truth this time or not, but the inconsistencies and improbabilities in his testimonies make it look that all the pages are fraud.
He says --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That shows the credibility doesn't it?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor it does but when you get so many of them I think it comes --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And credibility is a little below a constitutional question, isn't it?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor just on credibility but you also get a statistical impossibility when there are so many of these inconsistencies.
So many of the things he puts up to implicate this to Juhl.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's still one witness's credibility.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's still the fact that he's also testified on these very same facts under oath --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well normally in an ordinary criminal trial you know the credibility left to the triar of facts usually.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: But Your Honor we have a provision here which covers under the manual itself, I think that alone is enough regardless of Section 76 but if it's not, the manual for court-martials provide in Section 153 (a) and this is an instruction to the court-martial panel, you cannot face a conviction upon the un-corroborated testimony of an accomplice, if that testimony is self-contradictory, uncertain or improbable.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And who is to be the Judge of that?
The court?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: I think, not that court necessarily Your Honor, if the record shows that no other conclusion can be reached, if you have a jury trial.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have anything in your case other than the credibility of the witnesses?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor I've got the assurance of the -- it's not just the credibility of the witnesses, it's the question of all these facts showing that no other conclusion can be reached then --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is this man still in the army?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He is still serving?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: In the air force.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He is in air force.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you want us to approve paying him his back pay.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: While he's still in the air force?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you don't see a disciplinary problem either do you?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, your -- not -- when it conflicts with the constitutional right of a fair trial.

And I don't think he got this here and I think they violated Section 153A which tells them the court-martial panel itself you cannot base a conviction upon the uncooperated testimony of an accomplice where that testimony is uncertain or improper.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well that's just like an instruction isn't?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, no I don't believe it is Your Honor, not at all.
This is the statement through the court-martial panel.
This was in the manual for court-martials which was by Executive Order and referred back to Congress for approval.
This is what the court-martial can do and this is where it cannot convict.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: (Inaudible) is a daily matter for the enforcement of the narcotic laws that the government uses narcotic addiction notoriously irresponsible and untruthful, will have a string of convictions, maybe a block long.
Doesn't the government use those people as a principle witness in their cases?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well yes, Your Honor.
But when their testimony --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Does that deprive the Court of Jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, if the facts were the same as this I would say yes, I would say with all of the self contradictions and the improbabilities in his testimony, if that was the only evidence, it wouldn't be sufficient to convict.
If that where the only -- based upon the facts of this case, with the contradictions that we have in his own testimony, where the man you cannot read this record.
From back to the front and not conclude that the man was lying, I do not believe.
And where that is there can be no reasonable doubt about it.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there any other evidence besides him in this case?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: None that would tie him -- this is not corroborated, there is other testimony.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Nothing that would corroborate him?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Nothing that would corroborate him, Your Honor.
I do not believe.
Now this is -- this may be a judgment.

Also again, I believe reading the record that not -- this is not controverting fact, that is where what does this really, but just the only conclusion you can reach, the only conclusion you can reach, is that it's not corroborative.
There is no one -- for example, they have the sales girls, he said the government stated that it was corroborated by them and he purchased unusual amounts.
The sales girl said he did not purchase that this is -- whether it was -- irregular amounts or excessive amount.
And they said no, he purchased what was normal and he purchased large amounts but never in excess of his rights.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But didn't she also testify that they would punch it twice in the same hole on his ration card?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I don't think she testified to that.
She didn't say she did that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Somebody did in the record.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, yes Your Honor they are.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that would look like it was getting more than the usual amount.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor this -- she said that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It would usually save hole for two cottons.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: She did -- she said she did this for some people, but again this is another.
This is really the key to this whole case.
This is the reason the air force convicted him.
This is the reason, they seized this ration card illegally from him, which obviously has marks over, where he purchased more than the normal amount.
This was seized illegally and it was not used at the court-martial.
But the government had used it every sense, including the reply to this brief.
Now I asked my client about this, and he said that this -- these things were old on his card, what they did, they called him in and ordered him to produce it.

He said they were old and I wondered about that when I went to prison I took my other card that I had up there and I gave it -- I had it stamped, cut and when I happened to ask Curt and sure enough he sent me his card which is in evidence.
Where it shows where they cut his and it didn't cut it out all together.
In other words it was necessary to do it twice, is that true, I don't know.

But the thing is that was seized illegally, it was not part of that trial, there was no way for him to defend it, but that is the very reason, that is the very reason that this man has been convicted and put where he is now and they had refused to do anything about it.

And it was illegally seized and it's something that should never have been brought up and if it should have been, it should have been taken properly and he should have a right to explain it, which he did have an explanation.
And there was no question about it being seized illegally, the government admits that and it was not used at the court-martial.
But even then there is no where comparable that the -- what they charged him with and what they tried him with he was not guilty of, it was clear fabrication.
The government argues on Habeas Corpus that is more limit than what this Court has defined Habeas Corpus to be.
This man is still in the service.Every time his file jacket is open this conviction is part of that.
Every time he comes up for promotion and every time he is considered for any job, this is all part of it.
And under the recent case of Carafas v. LaVallee, the Court defined Habeas Corpus.
The government's initial brief was that well he wasn't in confinement, but this man was in confinement, he was out and it's a restraint that still follow.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, this is not a Habeas Corpus case is it?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor the same rules would apply.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No, this is not Habeas Corpus case.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: We are not seeking the relief, but I believe the same principle applies.
He is seeking something that is due him and the same theory of Habeas Corpus should apply.
Now this is a man who was confined, these are restraints that still follow him.
This perfectly qualified as a Habeas Corpus action, that he still has a restraint on him because of this conviction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: My great difficulty is that none of that is in the purview of the Court of Claims.
So all in the Court of Claims can do is to give him his back pay.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: He has the right to his back pay, under the Court of Claims Jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Period.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Under the constitution.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But can the Court of Claims issue writ of Habeas Corpus?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor they cannot.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Of course not.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: But as a practical man --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then why you are trying to put them together?
Court of Claims is the Court of limited Jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor he has been constitutionally deprived of his property and even if it's a smaller amount he's still being deprived of it, and the Court of Claims has jurisdiction to rule upon that, on his constitutional deprivation of salary.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- look on whether or not gets his back pay.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I do not believe it's the equivalent of that in the first place.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are going to extend the Court of Claims jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

But when this happens and I know of no case otherwise, the Correction Board, when this decision becomes final in effect corrects the record on application based upon that decision and I haven't heard of any decision where it was otherwise.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, that's what you want to do now.
You want to get us to pay us on and so you can go to the Correction of Records Board in the air force, is that what you want?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor I'll do that as soon as this decision --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, have you applied there yet?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And is it being held?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or have they ruled?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: They denied it and this is another basis for jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They denied it, so you really appealing from that denial aren't you?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
No Your Honor.
Well I am yes, I am questioning that opinion.
In my brief, I say this is another basis for jurisdiction.
In the first place, one under the correction statute the secretary can attack a court-martial.
In other words Section 76 of the Finality Clause says that these -- this decision on a court-martial will be final on all officers.
But then they come along with the correction statute where the Secretary wants to correct them to save Congress from making private bills.
So the Mr. Francis J. Steiner General rules and the government agree the Secretary can than collaterally attack the court-martial.
The Secretary can do that.
Now the decision of the Secretary is just final on officers, it's not final on Courts.
All the decisions of the Secretary under the Correction Board can be reviewed by the Court of Claims.
There is no basis in the legislative history or any other thing to show that they could not review a court-martial.
Nowhere does it say that and the government admits that the Secretary can collaterally attack it, that's an exception to Section 76.
And the statute under which he does it is only final on officers, it's not final on courts.
So under the correction statute he has a right to be reviewed in the Court of Claims under this, nowhere does it say otherwise.

But even the Section 76 found, and I believe under the decisions of this Court in Estep versus U.S. and the Harmon v. Brucker case, we had other statutes which had finality provisions in them, there was a finality provision in the law.
And the Court looked at this in effect as a final legal order.
They can make a final legal order, they don't consider all orders final, just only the final legal order.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did you go to the Court on Military Appeals?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor.
This is another thing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: He had no appeal, he could not take it up, he could not even ask him to review it.
There was no appeal whatsoever.
The one man that reviewed it was in the convening authority who was a staff judge advocate, who was a military lawyer.
He is also the same man who reviewed the specifications and advised suit to be filed and advised on the wording of them.
In other words, the only review was by the prosecutor in effect, this -- just this court-martial itself there was nowhere he could go.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Do you mean that the Court of Military Appeals had no jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: That's right Your Honor, not even to consider whether they would review it.
There was nothing he could do.
No where to go, this was the only court that could possibly consider his constitutional claims.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That is because of the minor, the minor penalty that was put on his --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now does that mean that every, every penalty that, in the armed forces, it is so minor that it cannot get to the Court of Military Appeals has a right to go direct to the Court of Claims?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, if it's a constitutional depravation, I believe under like Thompson versus City of Louisville where we had a $20 fine.
This was constitutional; this was taken away from him constitutionally.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Here there was no way, no review he had at all.
This is not a question on corroboration for example of any controverted facts, the record has to be read.
But the record as read shows this constitutional depravation that it was not corroborated.
It also was not waived as, if it's jurisdictional, which I believe that it is under this 153A.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is there some sort of collateral relief inside the military?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: The Board for the Correction of Military Record is the only thing Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What section is that under 67?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: 1552A 28 U.S.C. -- 10 U.S.C excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What does that involve?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Your honor, there the secretary has given the authority to review, to correct any record point in justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did that involve jury or is that on the record and -?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: He can do, he can take a hearing, he gathered all the records and he will accept any evidence you have, affidavits or he can also hold a hearing, many times it's just decided just upon the record.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you have a board, do we appoint a board for that purpose or -- a permanent board or you have a --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Your honor, I'm not sure of the exact procedure -- they do have someone over here who does this work, who reviews it, and says this is what can be done.
The statute reads the secretary of a military department under procedures established by him and approved by the Secretary of Defense and acting through boards of civilians of the executive.
Part of that -- acting through boards of civilians.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That indicates there's a board.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, through the executive part of that military department may correct any military record of that department when he considers it necessary to correct an error or remove an injustice, and that is then reviewable in the Court of Claims, they considered in this correction statute should we make it final on the courts, in the legislative history and they didn't, they struck that out –

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could you, are there some jurisdictional limits on what the board can do in the sense could they have reconsidered your case?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, they did consider it and deny it.
I believe there's no limits whatsoever I think Custer's lieutenant was correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You say you could have had your review on the Court of Claims from that?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor, I could review the Board of Correction of Military Records in the Court of Claims.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: By filing a suit for back pay?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which is what you've done?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Now, the government admits that you can do this.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, now if you're going to do that.
If that's the way, would you say you have a de novo review here or not?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would it be on the record of the board of review?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, the measurement is whether it's arbitrary and capricious and not supported by substantial evidence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I suppose and following up the question I ask you -- we would have to say, if we agreed with you, that in every conviction, military conviction where the punishment was so small that it could not be reviewed by the Court of Military Appeals that this court would have the responsibility of eventually reviewing these cases just on the record of the military trial.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I believe that so, and I believe it's a constitutional deprivation.
Here this man could have been sentenced to 16 years in prison but this record was so unreliable that even they couldn't believe it.
What they must have reacted on was he was charged, so he must be guilty so we're giving six months and then there is no review.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that – that difference between your case and the Augenblick case namely that you did apply to the Board for Correction of Records and had its determination before you went to the Court of Claims.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: I have two distinctions, that's one Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's one -- but I just want to be sure in the Augenblick case, that did not happen.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know about Augenblick.

There's something I know that they did not make it an issue in the Court of Claims on whether that was exceeded, whether they had appealed under the Board of Correction but I hate to say on Augenblick, on this thing.
But there are other differences, one --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're saying that whatever may it be, as I understand you now, whatever may be the interpretation on ‘76 that there is review in the Court of Claims of the determination of the Board to correct the records because Congress considered having the same prohibition against judicial review as determinations of that Board and rejected that in this case.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: This legislative history as in Ashe v. McNamara that they discuss it --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The express statute which grants the Court of Claims this kind of jurisdiction to review appellate jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor the Court of Claims has jurisdiction under any statute treaty or constitution and this would be under a statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean, namely a pay statute?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the pay statute and also the Correction Board statute because the secretary under the statute is given authority to correct an error or remove an injustice.
If that decision is arbitrary and capricious and not supported by substantial evidence, he can then take it to the Court of Claims.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now that's -- and your authority for that is what just logic or --?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the correction statute and the legislative history Your Honor and the wordings of the two statutes Section 76.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do either one of -- does any of the statute say that this kind of a determination may be reviewed in the Court of Claims?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I know what they say a court-martial specially be reviewed, but they have reviewed, the attorney general says the secretary can review this.
There is no basis in the history for distinguishing between the decisions of the secretary.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well I suppose if Shapiro was considered by the Congress in the context of all of this.
Shapiro at least indicated that there was authority in the Court of Claims to act on these claims.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What you are saying is when they came up, as I understand you now, on the applications made for review to the Board of Corrections of Records, that they considered the same kind of the prohibition against additional review that we have in ‘76 and rejected it, is that what you're telling?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Yes Your Honor, they considered shall we make this finding final on the courts and they struck it out, that's in the legislative history.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You've got that in your brief?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, well, I've citied in Ashe v. McNamara which has a full discussion of it, which I've referred from Ashe v. McNamara to the legislative history, but in addition one what the difference is --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What brief is that you state your evidence?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: In Your Honor where -- it's in my brief that a filed here, where I've citied --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: This brief?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Here it is.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes that -- Your Honor on page 14 of my brief, on the second paragraph the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Steiner you've filed more than a memorandum on opposition, didn't you?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
I've filed a brief, reply brief of the respondent Kenneth N. Juhl.

But the two circuits, the two circuits, the First and Tenth Circuit have construed this correction statute to give them authority to review court-martials and Ashe v. McNamara is one and Smith v. McNamara is the other.
So this and there is no decision saying that the courts cannot look into court-martials under the Correction Board statute.
The only case closest is Davies v. Clifford, which the government citied, in which they said that he was -- he received full relief from the secretary so we had no claim under that.

So my main difference is though that I made with Augenblick was the Correction Board statute, the fact that there was no review whatsoever for this man, not even discretionary and the fact that this is jurisdictional, this was basic jurisdiction under 153A.
The court-martial cannot base the conviction upon the uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice, where it's uncertain, doubtful or improbable.
That was jurisdiction that told them what they could do.
Those three factors are the reasons that turn in.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: To what extent must, must it be corroborated?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: I think with any corroboration Your Honor that its corroboration but you can't read just, for example the testimonies of the people who said, yes he was out here, but he didn't engage in any of this activity.
In fact he went around and sat in the front yard with my wife and I was so surprised to see him come out.
In other words, he contradicted Hughes on everything that Hughes said to implicate it, contradicted him on every single factor.
Now that can't be corroboration just because he was out there and he went around to sit there in the front yard, where his wife also in a later affidavit says he was in the front yard the whole time.
And Hughes's testimony on that there he said, once he rode out there with me and he stood beside the car and acted as a lookout.
Later at the trial, he says he went out into the road down the driveway to act as a lookout.
He testified at the Article 32, all these cigars boxes we are sitting right on the front seat where he could see it.
The other man comes up and says they were in the truck and there weren't anyway he could have seen.
This was the corroborating witnesses.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You say the other man --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, the other, the other possible collaborator, in other words he contradicting on everything and –-

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The fact they were contradicted with the --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor but --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: They told it?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor but that has to be corroborate -- in other words he didn't corroborate on any of the criminal factors and Hughes didn't repeat that testimony at the trial.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Who said the cigars --?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: This was the Article 33.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Who said the cigars were in the front seat?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Hughes, Hughes, the name the name of accomplish, the man we complain off.
He said they were –

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The car in which the defendant was when they went to sell this --

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, He said they were sitting in the front seat.
Now he said --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now why isn't that that corroboration?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: That's his testimony, his testimony has to be corroborating.

He is Hughes, he has testified it, his testimony but he didn't repeat that at the trial because (Inaudible) said, no it was in the trunk, there weren't anyway you could have seen, but these are just replete with this through out this record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: For the courtwide reasons -- now let me ask you –

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now I understand you now to be fair that despite the conviction, despite the Board of Appeals in the military, there is still a limit provided in a Code section for an examination by a board and if they decide against the man, the soldier there, he can have that reviewed in the Court of Appeal in the Court of Claim.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor that's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is that code section that authorize it?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: 10USCA 1552(a) I've cited it on page 2 of my brief.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has the government said anything about that in its brief?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well Your Honor they say that this, well this is okay for the secretary to do it, but it doesn't, they didn't mean to vary but there is no provision, that they didn't mean that a Court could then review it.
But there is no basis --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In Court of Claims do you say it authorizes the Court of Claims, is that set out anywhere in your brief or you just refer to it.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, this is one of my basic arguments Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But is it set out in your brief in the Court section?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor it is, I've cited.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But is it quoted?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor it's quoted.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: On page 2.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Of the reply brief?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But it doesn't say anything about the Court of Claims.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor.
But in the legislative history they said --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well does that say?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Will be filed just on officers and that they consider will it be on court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It says officers.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: It says officers and they deleted courts.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well and then say it in the statute and the Court of Claims have never done it, is that right?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Pardon me Your Honor.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: It doesn't say in the statute and the Court of Claims has never reviewed that sort of a determination, am I right or wrong?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: You are right on that, that they have never reviewed a court-martial but two circuits have, two circuits have and --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No, but you were saying Court of Claims and in fact of the matter is statute does not mention the Court of Claims and the Court of Claims has never have reviewed it, has never exercised power that I understood you to assert that it has.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Well Your Honor I think if they were faced with a case directly in point, well that was the only basis they would construe it that way, now that's just conjecture but they haven't ruled that I know, that no this prohibits us from reviewing it.
And the thing is, it excluded any Court, this is general Court, they didn't specify courts could and which couldn't.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was that involved in the Ashe case.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
This is the very basis of the Ashe.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Plus the 28 U.S code.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now these two circuits that have that -- what cases are those?

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: The First and Tenth Circuit Your Honor Ashe versus McNamara.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Uh-huh.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Which is 3355 Federal Second 277, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's First circuit and the Tenth circuit case is.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Is Smith versus McNamara 395 F Second 896.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I thought those are habeas corpus cases.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor these were under the correction board statue Ashe for example was not in fact -- and they didn't hold in its favor and Smith, but they ruled they had jurisdiction in accordance of Ashe.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it there would be any limit on the nature of the attack which the secretary of the board under this section could have entertained.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: The secretary could do anything Your Honor I believe.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Under this section, he could just say –- he can say there has been an error here, because there wasn't enough evidence to sustain my conviction by the court-martial and the -– and so the Secretary could if he wanted to despite 76 review the evidence and then you would say the court might review him.

turn.speaker: francis_j_steiner
turn.label: Mr. Francis J. Steiner, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
Thank you.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Weisl.

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: Very briefly Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Was the certiorari sought in that Ashe you remember --

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: I don't believe it was Mr. Justice Douglas, the speaker as to the board question that has been the subject to extensive examination by the court -- there is a discussion in our brief of footnote 31 on page 46.
In this brief, our position that legislative history of the statute establishing the court provides that there maybe judicial review under appropriate circumstances.

The government I feel certainly would take the position that if the underlying action being reviewed by the board was a court-martial that the finality clause of Article 76 would bar judicial review of the board's decision.
The board's decision however --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Mr. Weisl -- what does this mean, I am reading from Ashe.

In light of this history, we are confident that the finality provision as it now exists quoting it “a correction under this section is finally conclusive on all offices of the United States, was not intended to conclude any otherwise proper judicial review of the departmental action upon a petition to change by petitioner”.

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: I think that case is clearly wrong to the extent that it says if you can review a board.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But it is contrary to your position.

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I see.
So we have to disapprove it then.

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I think you'll see it from the Court of Claims decision in Juhl that there are two questions --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Can I ask then before -- what about the other case, was there any proceeding before the Augenblick case, any effort to get a proceeding before a correction board in that case?

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: To the best of my knowledge, there was not --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I don't see any conflict in Ashe and your position here.

turn.speaker: edwin_l_weisl
turn.label: Mr. Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
turn.text: Here no, but I said if the question arose again whether the board for the correction of records could be reviewed in court when they have corrected a court-martial, we would urge that Article 76 bars judicial review of that board Ashe.

Yeah, finally in conclusion I would like to I think place this case in respect to both these cases by saying that I think we are all concerned about probably is whether a military defendant has access at some point to a civilian court to make sure that he was not convicted on fundamentally unfair grounds by fundamentally unfair procedures and briefly these are the instances under which a military defendant can at some point get civilian review by a civilian court.
He is imprisoned over one year; he can go to the Court of Military Appeals or of course habeas corpus.
He is dismissed from the service as was Augenblick; it's a bad conduct or dishonorable discharge.
He is an enlisted man; he can go to the Court of Military Appeals, which is a civilian court.

If he is imprisoned for less than one year, truly must act promptly, but he can seek the remedy of habeas corpus and that remedy has been made much more meaningful by this court, because even if he has properly applied for that writ, even though his imprisonment is over and he has served his term, this court has recently held in the Carafus v. LaVallee case that he can pursue his habeas remedy and have his conviction expunged.
Therefore, only in the petty area where a fine is imposed or a reduction in pay takes place is he foreclosed by review by habeas or the Court of Military Appeals.
I think that this situation shows that fundamentally the position the government has urged is fair, thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you Gentlemen.
